Let $ \mathbb{Z}_+$ be the set of all positive integers and $$ \mathcal{M}= \{ m\in \mathbb{Z}_+:\,\,\, 	ext{exist}\,\, m_1,m_2 \in \mathbb{Z}_+\,\,\, 	ext{such that }\,\,\, \max(m_1,m_2) \le m\,\,\, 	ext{and}\,\,\, m^2+m_1^2+m_2^2 = 3mm_1m_2 \} $$ be the set of all Markoff numbers. We write elements of $\mathcal{M}$ in increasing order as $$ \mathcal{M} :\,\,\, m(1) = 1 < m(2) =2 < m (3)=5 <...< m(
u) <... $$ and consider corresponding values $$ \mu_1 =  rac{1}{\sqrt{5}}> \mu_2 = rac{1}{\sqrt{8}}> \mu_3 = rac{5}{\sqrt{221}}>... > \mu_
u =  rac{1}{\sqrt{9-  rac{4}{m(
u)^2}}}> ... $$ One of the corollaries of the famous theorem about the discrete part of Markoff and Lagrange spectra (see \cite{cas}, Chapter II and \cite{Cus}) may be formulated as follows. \vskip+0.3cm { f Theorem A}. {\it Let $ \gamma$ be a real number satisfying $$ \mu_{
u+1} < \gamma < \mu_
u. $$ If for a real number $\alpha$ inequality $$ \left| \alpha - rac{p}{q}ight|<  rac{\gamma}{q^2} $$ has infinitely many rational solutions $ rac{p}{q} \in \mathbb{Q}$, then for this $\alpha$ a stronger inequality $$ \left| \alpha - rac{p}{q}ight|<  rac{\mu_{
u+1} }{q^2} $$ has infinitely many rational solutions $ rac{p}{q}$. } \vskip+0.3cm One of the the proofs of Theorem A contain as an ingredient a special statement about "isolation" of the values of binary indefinite quadratic forms corresponding to Markoff numbers (see \cite{cas} Theorem I from Chapter II). \vskip+0.3cm On the other hand, quite recently Han\v{c}l \cite{H} proved a result which can be reformulated as follows. \vskip+0.3cm { f Theorem B}. {\it For $x\ge 1$ consider function $$ \psi_
u (x) =  rac{2\mu_
u}{\left(1+\sqrt{1+ rac{4\mu_
u^2}{x^2}}ight) x^2}<  rac{\mu_
u}{x^2}. $$ If for a real number $\alpha$ inequality $$ \left| \alpha - rac{p}{q}ight|<  rac{\mu_
u}{q^2} $$ has infinitely many rational solutions $ rac{p}{q} \in \mathbb{Q}$, then for this $\alpha$ a stronger inequality $$ \left| \alpha - rac{p}{q}ight| \leqslant \psi_
u (q) $$ has infinitely many rational solutions $ rac{p}{q}$. } \vskip+0.3cm The results mentioned above motivated us to prove a general statement concerning solutions of inequalities of the form  egin{equation}\label{dsf} \left| \alpha - rac{p}{q}ight|<  rac{ f(q)}{q^2} \end{equation} with positive function $f(x)<1$. We will deal with functions $$ f(x),\,\,\, f_1(x) = f(x) - g(x),\,\,\, f(x) >f_1(x) >0 $$ under the condition that there is no real $\alpha$ such that simultaneously inequality (ef{dsf}) has infinitely many rational solutions $ rac{p}{q}$ and the inequality  egin{equation}\label{dsf1} \left|\alpha - rac{p}{q}ight|< rac{f_1(q)}{q^2} \end{equation} has not more than a finite number of solutions in rationals $ rac{p}{q}$; in other words, existence of infinitely many solutions of inequality (ef{dsf}) leads to existence of infinitely many solutions of inequality (ef{dsf1}). In our constructions function $f(x)$ can decrease to zero as quickly as desired. These results may have relation to problems of mutual behaviour of two irrationality measure functions for real numbers (see \cite{KM, M, SR}). \vskip+0.3cm

sections.title: Approximation to one real number
sections.content:
First of all we formulate a general result for arbitrary functions $f(x)$. \vskip+0.3cm { f Theorem 1.} {\it Consider arbitrary function $f (x):\mathbb{Z}_+ 	o (0,1]$. Then there exists $ \gamma \in (0,1)$ and a function $g(x) :\mathbb{Z}_+ 	o (0,1]$ such that $$ 0< g(x) < f(x), \,\,\,\,\, 	ext{for all}\,\,\, x\in \mathbb{Z}_+ $$ and for any real $\alpha$ the following statement holds: \vskip+0.3cm 
oindent if inequality $$ \left| \alpha - rac{p}{q}ight|<  rac{\gamma \cdot f(q)}{q^2} $$ has infinitely many solutions in rationals $ rac{p}{q} \in \mathbb{Q}$, then a stronger inequality $$ \left| \alpha - rac{p}{q}ight|<  rac{\gamma \cdot f(q)- g(q)}{q^2} $$ also has infinitely many solutions in rationals $ rac{p}{q} \in \mathbb{Q}$.} \vskip+0.3cm Of course, function $g(x)$ from Theorem 1 does not depend on $\alpha$. Theorem 1 is a particular case of a general statement which we formulate in Section ef{fri} as Theorem 3. To formulate this general result we need to discuss properties of Diophantine approximations for systems of linear forms in Section ef{DAA} and consider some related functions in Section ef{FF}. Theorem 1 will immediately follow from Theorem 3 and Lemma 2. \vskip+0.3cm In the case when $f(x)$ takes rational values only we have an effective version of Theorem 1. Let  egin{equation}\label{fq} f(x) =  rac{A(x)}{B(x)}, \,\,\,\, A(x)\in \mathbb{Z},\,\,\ \,B(x) \in \mathbb{Z}_+,\,\,\,\, (A(x),B(x)) = 1. \end{equation} Define  egin{equation}\label{gq} g_f(x) =  rac{(f(x))^2\cdot f\left(  rac{A(x)x^2}{f(x)}+2ight)}{(A(x)x)^2} . \end{equation} It is clear that $ 0< g_f(x) <f(x)$ for every $x>1$. Moreover, if $f(x)$ is decreasing, then  egin{equation}\label{gqdec} g_f(x) \le  rac{(f(x))^3}{ x^2} . \end{equation} \vskip+0.3cm { f Theorem 2.} {\it Let $f (x) : \mathbb{Z}_+ 	o \mathbb Q_{+}\cap (0,1]$ be a non-strictly decreasing function. Let $\alpha$ be real number. Assume that the inequality  egin{equation}\label{4y} \left| \alpha - rac{p}{q}ight|<  rac{ f(q)}{q^2} \end{equation} has infinitely many solutions in rationals $ rac{p}{q} \in \mathbb{Q}$. Then for any positive $\varepsilon>0$ a stronger inequality  egin{equation}\label{5y} \left| \alpha - rac{p}{q}ight|<  rac{ f(q)- (1-\varepsilon)g_f(q)}{q^2} \end{equation} where $g_f(x) $ is defined in (ef{gq}) also has infinitely many solutions in rationals $ rac{p}{q} \in \mathbb{Q}$.} \vskip+0.3cm We give a proof of Theorem 2 in Section ef{t2p}. \vskip+0.3cm To illustrate Theorem 2 we consider three examples. 
oindent 	extbf{ 1.} Let $f(x)$ be just a rational constant $f(q) =  rac{A}{B} \in \mathbb{Q},\,\, orall\, q$. Then $g_f(x) =  rac{A}{B^3x^2}. $ 
oindent 	extbf{ 2.} Let $f(x) =  rac{1}{x^{\sigma}},$ where $\sigma \in \mathbb{Z}_+.$ Then $g_f(x) =  rac{1}{(x^{2+\sigma}+2)^\sigma x^{2\sigma+2}} \sim  rac{1}{x^{\sigma^2+4\sigma +2}}, x 	o \infty$. 
oindent 	extbf{ 3.} Let $f(x) =  rac{1}{2^x},$ then $g_f(x) =  rac{1}{x^2 2^{x^2\cdot 2^x+2x+2}} $.

sections.title: Matrices and approximations
sections.content: \label{DAA} Let $m,n\ge 1$ and \begin{equation}\label {vaa} \Theta =\left( \begin{array}{ccc} \theta_{1,1}&\cdots&\theta_{m,1}\cr \cdots &\cdots &\cdots \cr \theta_{1,n}&\cdots&\theta_{m,n} \end{array} \right) \end{equation} be a real matrix. The main topic of the theory of linear Diophantine approximation is analysis of behaviour of linear forms $\sum_{i=1}^m\theta_{j}q_i - p_j$ when variables $q_i, 1\le i \le m $; $p_j, 1\le j \le n$ take integer values. We use notation $$ q = (q_1,...,q_m) \in \mathbb{Z}^m,\,\,\,\, p = (p_1,...,p_n) \in \mathbb{Z}^n, \,\,\,\, |q| = \max_{1\le i \le m} |q_i|,\,\,\,\, ||\Theta q|| = \min_{p\in \mathbb{Z}^n} |\Theta q - p|. $$ The set of all matrices (\ref{vaa}) with entries $\theta_{i,j} \in [0,1]$ we denote by $\mathcal{R}$. Fundamental Dirichlet's theorem claims that there exist infinitely many $q\in \mathbb{Z}^m\setminus \{ (0,...,0)\}$ such that $$ ||\Theta q|| \le \frac{1}{|q|^{{m}/{n}}}. $$ We deal with the set of positive integers $\mathbb{Z}_+$, the set of positive rationals $\mathbb{Q}_+$ and the set of positive reals $\mathbb{R}_+$. Consider function $f:\mathbb{Z}_+ \to (0,1]$. \vskip+0.3cm For integer vector $q\in \mathbb{Z}^m\setminus \{ (0,...,0)\}$ define sets $$ M_q = M_q [f]=\left\{\Theta \in \mathcal{R}: \,\, ||\Theta q||< \frac{f(|q|)}{2 |q|^{{m}/{n}} }\right\},\,\,\,\, {M}_q^c = M_q^c [f]= \mathcal{R}\setminus M_q $$ and $$ \mathcal{M} = \mathcal{M}[f]= \bigcap_{Q=1}^\infty\,\,\, \bigcup_{q\in \mathbb{Z}^m: \, |q|\ge Q} M_q,\,\,\,\,\,\, \mathcal{M}^c = \mathcal{M}^c[f]= \bigcup_{Q=1}^\infty \,\,\, \bigcap_{q\in \mathbb{Z}^m: \, |q|\ge Q} M_q^c. $$ Consider strips $$ W_{q,p} = \left\{ \Theta \in \mathcal{R}: \,\, |\Theta q - p|< \frac{f(|q|)}{|q|^{{m}/{n}}} \right\}. $$ We should note that for every $Q$ the set $$ \mathcal{N}_Q = \mathcal{R} \setminus \left(\bigcup_{q\in \mathbb{Z}^m: \, |q|\ge Q}\,\,\, \bigcup_{p\in \mathbb{Z}^n} W_{q,p} \right) = \bigcap_{q\in \mathbb{Z}^m: \, |q|\ge Q} \left\{\Theta \in \mathcal{R}: \,\, ||\Theta q||\ge \frac{f(|q|)}{ |q|^{{m}/{n}} }\right\}, $$ is non-where dense in $\mathcal{R}$. It is clear that $ \Theta \in \mathcal{M}$ if and only if \begin{equation}\label{1x} \forall\, Q\,\,\, \exists \, q \in \mathbb{Z}^m \,\,\,\text{such that}\,\,\, |q| \ge Q \,\,\, \text{and} \,\,\, ||\Theta q || < \frac{f(|q|)}{2|q|^{m/n}}, \end{equation} meanwhile $ \Theta \in \mathcal{M}^c$ if and only if \begin{equation}\label{2x} \exists\, Q\,\,\, \forall \, q \in \mathbb{Z}^m \,\,\,\text{such that}\,\,\, |q| \ge Q\,\,\,\text{one has }\,\,\, ||\Theta q || \ge \frac{f(|q|)}{2|q|^{m/n}}. \end{equation} In particular, as $f(x) >0$ for every $x \in \mathbb{Z}_+$, the set $\mathcal{M}^c$ does not contain any matrix $\Theta$ such that the { columns} $$ \underbrace{ \left( \begin{array}{c} \theta_{1,1} \cr \vdots \cr \theta_{1,n} \end{array} \right), \,\,\, \dots \, , \left( \begin{array}{c} \theta_{m,1} \cr \vdots \cr \theta_{m,n} \end{array} \right)}_m, \,\,\, \underbrace{ \left( \begin{array}{c} 1 \cr \vdots \cr 0 \end{array} \right), \,\,\, \dots \, , \left( \begin{array}{c} 0 \cr \vdots \cr 1 \end{array} \right)}_n $$ are linearly dependent over $\mathbb{Q}$.

sections.title: Family $ \frak{F
sections.content:
$}\label{FF} For fixed $m,n$ we consider a family of functions $f:\mathbb{Z}_+ 	o (0,1]$ defined by $$  rak{F} = \{f:\mathbb{Z}_+ 	o \mathbb{R}_+:\,\,\,	ext{there exists}\,\,\, Q = Q[f] \,\,\, 	ext{such that for every}\,\,\, \Theta \in \mathcal{M}^c[f] $$ $$\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, 	ext{and for every} \,\,\, q\in \mathbb{Z}^m \,\,\,	ext{with}\,\,\, |q|\ge Q \,\,\, 	ext{one has }\,\,\, |q| ^{m/n}\cdot ||\Theta q|| 
eq f(|q|) \}. $$ Here we would like to mention two examples of functions from the family $ rak{F}$. \vskip+0.3cm { f Lemma 1.} Let function $ h(x): \mathbb{Z}_+	o (0,1] $ decreases to zero and takes only positive rational values. Then function $f(x) = x^{m/n} h(x)$ belongs to $ rak{F}$. \vskip+0.3cm Proof. Suppose that $ f(x) 
ot\in  rak{F}$. Then there exists matrix $\Theta$ and an infinite sequence of vectors $q\in \mathbb{Z}^m$ such that $ ||\Theta q|| = h(|q|)$. Then for some $i \in \{ 1,...,n\}$ there exists a sequence $\mathcal{Q} \subset { \mathbb{{Z}}^{m+1}}$ of vectors $ \overline{q} = (q_0 ,q_1,...,q_m)\in \mathbb{Z}^{m+1}$ such that  egin{equation}\label{iir} |	heta_1q_1 + ...+	heta_m q_m+ q_0|= \ h(q) \in \mathbb{Q}\cap (0,1] \,\,\, orall \overline{q} \in \mathcal{Q}. \end{equation} (for brevity we write here $	heta_j = 	heta_{i,j}, 1\le j \le m$ and denote $	heta = (	heta_1,...,	heta_m)\in \mathbb{R}^m$). Now we will show that for any real vector $	heta$ and infinite $\mathcal{Q}$ condition (ef{iir}) with $ h(x) 	o 0, x	o\infty$ is impossible. We proceed by induction in $m$. For $m=1$ equality (ef{iir}) can be rewritten as $$ |	heta_1 q_1 + q_0| = h(q_1). $$ Now it is clear that $ 	heta_1 =  rac{a}{b}$ is a rational number and so $$ \left|  rac{aq_1 + bq_0}{b}ight| = h(q_1) $$ for all vectors $ (q_0,q_1)$ from infinite $\mathcal{Q}$. When $q_1 	o \infty$ this leads to $ h(q_1) = |	heta_1 q_1 + q_0| = 0$, and this is not possible by the condition $h(x) >0$. This gives the base of induction. Now we show that the statement for $m\ge 2$ variables can be reduced to the statement for $ { r < m}$ variables. Assume that (ef{iir}) is valid for an infinite sequence $\mathcal{Q}$. We distinguish two cases. In case ({ f A}) we assume that there exists $m$ solutions $$ (q_{0,k},q_{1,k},...,q_{m,k}) \in \mathbb{Z}^{m+1},\,\,\, 1\le k \le m $$ of the equality (ef{iir}) such that $$ {m det}\, \left(  egin{array}{ccc} q_{1,1}&...&q_{m,1}\cr ...&...&...\cr q_{1,m}&...&q_{m,m} \end{array} ight) 
eq 0. $$ In this case, by Cramer's formula all the numbers $	heta_j $ are rational. Then writing $ 	heta_j =  rac{a_j}{b_j}, a_j \in\mathbb{Z}, b_j \in \mathbb{Z}_+$ we see that any linear combination $ q_0+	heta_1 q_1 + ...+	heta_m q_m $ is {a} rational number with denominator $ {m l.c.m} (b_1,..,b_m)$. So if for a certain infinite sequence of vectors $q$, linear combinations (ef{iir}) tend to zero, necessarily these linear combinations are eventually just equal to zero. So there are large values of $q$, such that $h(|q|) = 0$. This contradicts to the condition on $h(x)$. In case ({ f B}) equality from (ef{iir}) does not have $m$ independent solutions. This means that there exists a proper linear subspace $\mathcal{V}\in \mathbb{R}^m$ such that for every solution of (ef{iir}) the corresponding truncated vector $q= (q_1,...,q_m)$ belongs to $\mathcal{V}$. We may assume the $\mathcal{V}$ is the minimal linear subspace with this property. Then $\mathcal{V}$ is a rational subspace in $\mathbb{R}^m$ and $r = {m dim} \mathcal{V} <m$. Consider the lattice $\Gamma = \mathcal{V}\cap \mathbb{Z}^m$, and let vectors $$ e_k = (q_{1,k}^*,...,q_{m,k}^*) \in \mathbb{Z}^{m}, \,\,\, 1\le k \le r $$ form a basis in $ \Gamma$. Any $q\in \mathcal{Q}\subset \Gamma $ may be written as a sum $$ q = \sum_{k=1}^r c_k(q) e_k ,\,\,\, c_k(q) \in \mathbb{Z},\,\, 1\le k \le r. $$ So for any $\overline{q} \in \mathcal{Q}$ we have $$ \left| \sum_{  egin{array}{c} 1\le j \le m\cr 1\le k \le r \end{array} } 	heta_j c_k(q) q_{j,k}^* +q_0ight| = h(|q|). $$ Now we define $r<m$ real numbers $$ 	heta_k' = \sum_{j=1}^m 	heta_j q_{j,k}^* ,\,\,\, 1\le k \le r $$ for which there exists an infinite sequence $\mathcal{Q}'$ of vectors $$ \overline{q}' = (q_0', q_1',...,q_r') = (q_0 , c_1 (q),...,c_r(q) ) \in \mathbb{Z}^{r+1},\,\,\, \overline{q} \in \mathcal{Q} $$ such that $$ |	heta_1q_1' +...+	heta_r'q_r'+q_0'| = h(|q|) \in \mathbb{Q}\cap (0,1],\,\,\, h(|q|) 	o 0. $$ By inductive assumption this is not possible.$\Box$ \vskip+0.3cm Our next lemma deals with a special case $m=n=1$. \vskip+0.3cm { f Lemma 2.} Let $m=n=1$. Then for any function $f:\mathbb{Z}_+ 	o (0,1] $ there exists a positive $\gamma$ such that $\gamma \cdot f \in  rak{F}.$ \vskip+0.3cm Proof. Recall that for $m=n=1$ the set $ \mathcal{N}_Q$ { is} non-where dense in $[0,1]$. Consider the set $$ \mathcal{N}_{Q;q,p} = \left\{ eta =  rac{q}{f(q)} \cdot |q\alpha - p|,\,\,\, \alpha \in \mathcal{N}_Qight\} $$ (here $q,p \in \mathbb{Z}$). This set is also non-where dense in $[0,1]$. At the same time $\gamma \cdot f 
ot\in  rak{F}$ if and only if  egin{equation}\label{3x} \gamma \in  igcup_{Q} igcup_{q} igcup_{p} \mathcal{N}_{Q;q,p}. \end{equation} The right hand side of (ef{3x}) is a countable union of non-where dense sets. By Baire's theorem there exist $\gamma \in (0,1)$ which does not belong to this set.$\Box$

sections.title: General result and its proof
sections.content: \label{fri} {\bf Theorem 3.} {\it Let $f \in \frak{F}$. Then there exists a positive valued function $g:\mathbb{Z}_+\to (0,1]$ such that for any real matrix $\Theta $ the following statement is valid: if inequality \begin{equation}\label{4x} || \Theta q||< \frac{f(|q|)}{|q|^{m/n}} \end{equation} has infinitely many solutions in ${q}\in \mathbb{Z}^m$ then a stronger inequality \begin{equation}\label{5x} ||\Theta q ||< \frac{f(|q|)- g(|q|)}{|q|^{m/n}} \end{equation} also has infinitely many solutions in ${q}\in \mathbb{Z}^m$.} \vskip+0.3cm Lemma 1 from the previous section leads to the following \vskip+0.3cm {\bf Corollary.} {\it Let $f (x) : \mathbb{Z}_+ \to (0,1]$ be a non-strictly decreasing function such that $f(x) \cdot x^{-m/n}\in \mathbb{Q}$ for any integer $x$. Then there exists function $g:\mathbb{Z}_+\to (0,1]$ such that for any real matrix $\Theta $ solvability of (\ref{4x}) in infinitely many ${q}\in \mathbb{Z}^m$ leads to solvability of (\ref{5x}) in infinitely many ${q}\in \mathbb{Z}^m$. } \vskip+0.3cm Lemma 2 shows that Theorem 1 formulated in the beginning of our paper immediately follows from Theorem 3. \vskip+0.3cm Proof of Theorem 3. Define $g_1(x) = \frac{f(x)}{2}$. Each set $ M_q^c \subset \mathcal{R}$ is a compact set. As $f\in \frak{F}$, for $ x\ge Q[f]$ we define \begin{equation}\label{7x} g_2(x) = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \inf_{ \begin{array}{c} q\in \mathbb{Z}^m: |q|= x ;\cr \Theta\in M_q^c \end{array} }\,\, (f(x) - x^{m/n}\cdot ||\Theta q ||) =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \min_{ \begin{array}{c} q\in \mathbb{Z}^m: |q|= x ;\cr \Theta\in M_q^c \end{array} }\,\, (f(x) - x^{m/n}\cdot ||\Theta q ||) >0. \end{equation} The last inequality follows from compactness argument. Again we consider two cases. In the first case we assume that $\Theta\in \mathcal{M}$. Then we have the result of Theorem 2 with $ g(q) = g_1(q) $ because of (\ref{1x}). Consider the case $\Theta\in \mathcal{M}^c$. Then there exists an infinite sequence of integer vectors $q$ such that $ \Theta \in M_q^c$. By (\ref{7x}) for these values of $q$ with $ |q|\ge Q[f]$ we have $ |q|^{m/n}\cdot ||\Theta q||< f(|q|) - g_2(|q|)$. So we have the conclusion of Theorem 3 with $ g(x) = \min (g_1(x), g_2(x))$.$\Box$

sections.title: Proof of Theorem 2
sections.content: \label{t2p} We may assume that $\alpha$ is irrational. Consider its representation as an ordinary infinite continued fraction $$ \alpha = [a_0;a_1,a_2,...,a_n,...],\,\,\,\,\, a_0 \in \mathbb{Z}, \,\,\, a_j \in \mathbb{Z}_+, j \ge 1 $$ and define $$ \frac{p_n}{q_n} = [a_0;a_1,a_2,...,a_n], \,\,\,\,\, \alpha_{n+1} = [a_{n+1};a_{n+2},...,a_{n+k},...]. $$ It is well known (see for example \cite{RS}, Chapter 1, \S 6) that \begin{equation}\label{perron0} \alpha_n^* := \frac{q_{n-1}}{q_n} = [0;a_n,a_{n-1},...,a_{1}] \end{equation} and \begin{equation}\label{perron} |q_n \alpha - p_n| = \frac{1}{q_n (\alpha_{n+1}+\alpha_n^*)}. \end{equation} Define $$ \frac{p_{n,k}}{q_{n,k}} = [a_{n+1};a_{n+2},a_{n+3},...,a_{n+k}],\,\,\,\,\, \alpha_{n,k}^* = \frac{q_{n,k-1}}{q_{n,k}}= [0;a_{n+k},a_{n+k-1},....,a_{n+2}] . $$ Then application of (\ref{perron}) gives \begin{equation}\label{perron1} |q_{n,k} \alpha_{n+1} - p_{n,k}| = \frac{1}{q_{n,k} (\alpha_{n+k+1}+\alpha_{n,k}^*)}. \end{equation} \vskip+0.3cm Let us denote $ f_n = f(q_n)$. We will distinguish two cases. In the {\bf first case} we assume that there exist infinitely many values of $n$ such that \begin{equation}\label{c1} \frac{1}{\alpha_{n+1}+\alpha_n^*} < f_n \left(1-\left(\frac{f_n}{q_n}\right)^2\right). \end{equation} We see that in the {\bf first case} condition (\ref{c1}) together with (\ref{gqdec}) and (\ref{perron}) immediately gives infinitely many solutions of inequality (\ref{5y}). \vskip+0.3cm Now we consider the {\bf second case}, when inequality (\ref{c1}) if valid for not more than for a finite collection of values of $n$, Then there exists $n_0$ such that for all $n\ge n_0$ one has \begin{equation}\label{c2} \frac{1}{\alpha_{n+1}+\alpha_n^*} \ge f_n \left(1-\left(\frac{f_n}{q_n}\right)^2\right). \end{equation} In particular, \begin{equation}\label{c22} \frac{q_{n+1}}{q_n} = a_{n+1}+\alpha_n^* < \alpha_{n+1}+\alpha_n^*\le \frac{1}{f_n \left(1-\left(\frac{f_n}{q_n}\right)^2\right)} . \end{equation} By condition (\ref{4y}) and formula (\ref{perron}) we may assume that for infinitely many values of $n\ge n_0$ we have \begin{equation}\label{c3} \frac{1}{\alpha_{n+1}+\alpha_n^*} <f_n. \end{equation} In the rest of the proof we deal just with these values of $n$. We consider the value $$ 0< \delta_n= \alpha_{n+1}+\alpha_n^* -\frac{1}{f_n} = \alpha_{n+1} +\frac{q_{n-1}}{q_n} - \frac{1}{f_n} = \alpha_{n+1} - \frac{C_{n}}{A_nq_n}, $$ {where} $$ C_n = q_{n}B_{n} - q_{n-1}A_{n} \in \mathbb{Z},\,\,\, A_n = A(q_n),\,\,\, B_n = B(q_n) $$ (we used here (\ref{fq}) and (\ref{perron0})). Let us choose $k$ such that \begin{equation}\label{c31} q_{n,k} \le A_nq_n < q_{n,k+1}. \end{equation} Then by Lagrange's theorem on best approximations we get \begin{equation}\label{c5} A_nq_n\delta_n \ge |q_{n,k}\alpha_{n+1} -p_{n,k}|. \end{equation} Now from inequality (\ref{c5}), equality (\ref{perron1}), inequalities (\ref{c2}) and $$ |\alpha_{n+k}^* - \alpha_{n,k}^*|\le \frac{1}{q_{n,k}^2}, $$ we get $$ A_nq_n\delta_n \ge \frac{1}{q_{n,k}(\alpha_{n+k+1} + \alpha_{n,k}^*)}\ge \frac{1}{q_{n,k}(\alpha_{n+k+1} + \alpha_{n+k}^*+1/q_{n,k}^2)}\ge \frac{1}{ \frac{q_{n,k} }{f_{n+k}\left( 1- \left(\frac{f_{n+k}}{q_{n+k}}\right)^2\right)}+\frac{1}{q_{n,k}}} = $$ $$ \frac{f_{n+k}}{q_{n,k}} \left( 1-\frac{f_{n+k}}{ q_{n,k}^2} \right) \frac{1}{ 1+ \frac{f_{n+k} } {q_{n,k}^2 } \left( 1- \left(\frac{f_{n+k}}{q_{n+k}}\right)^2\right)} > \frac{f_{n+k}}{q_{n,k}} \left( 1-\frac{2f_{n+k}}{ q_{n,k}^2} \right) $$ for $n$ large enough. Then \begin{equation}\label{continuant} q_{n+k} \le (q_{n+1}+q_n) q_{n,k} \le q_n q_{n,k} \left( \frac{q_{n+1}}{q_n}+1\right) \le q_n q_{n,k} \cdot \left(\frac{1}{f_n \left(1-\left(\frac{f_n}{q_n}\right)^2\right)}+1\right), \end{equation} by (\ref{c22}). Taking into account the first inequality from (\ref{c31}) and monotonicity of $f(x)$, finally we obtain $$ \delta_n\ge \frac{f\left(A_n q_n^2\cdot \left(\frac{1}{f_n \left(1-\left(\frac{f_n}{q_n}\right)^2\right)}+1\right) \right) }{(A_nq_n)^2} \cdot \left( 1-\frac{2f_{n+k}}{ q_{n,k}^2} \right)> (1-\varepsilon) \frac{f\left(\frac{A_n q_n^2}{f_n}+2 \right) }{(A_nq_n)^2}, $$ for $n $ large enough. As $\alpha_{n+1}+\alpha_n^* >\frac{1}{f_n}+\delta_n$ by (\ref{perron}) we conclude that for any $\varepsilon>0$ for large $n$ under our consideration we have $$ \left|\alpha - \frac{p_n}{q_n}\right| < \frac{f_n}{q_n^2} \left( 1- (1-\varepsilon) \frac{ f_n \cdot f\left(\frac{A_n q_n^2}{f_n}+2 \right) }{(A_nq_n)^2}\right). $$ Theorem 2 is proven.$\Box$ \vskip+0.3cm {\bf Acknowledgements} \,\, Sergei Pitcyn's research is supported by Russian Scientific Foundation, grant no.~25-11-00112, https://rscf.ru/project/25-11-00112/.
